@ascrutae PTAL
ok, let me do it.

When you do this, please make sure it is either attched on every project, or aggregating all projects data into one graph, considering SkyWalking has many subprojects.
Also, we need this to rebuild every time.

> When you do this, please make sure it is either attched on every project, or aggregating all projects data into one graph, considering SkyWalking has many subprojects.
> Also, we need this to rebuild every time.

Good catch! Let me generate a graph contains all subprojects :)

And we will support one link target to a dynamic graph, so we don't have to update that graph every time.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2106987/113494850-0e37e100-951f-11eb-876e-2abb8e020606.png)

Yes, when I try to add all projects, I find that it has too many projects 😂 Could we attach this graph for every project? (on the README file instead of website).
It's not clear for repos that don't have too many contributors when combining all of the projects.

Do you mean api7 host service? Be careful anout it.
ASF TLP relies on commercial vendor website, which could be a concern by PMC, even ASF at policy level.

Yes, this graph is generated by API7, but for now, I will generate every graph by that service, without any commercial information actually 🤔 

> And we will support one link target to a dynamic graph, so we don't have to update that graph every time.

This feature is still in progress :)

> Yes, this graph is generated by API7, but for now, I will generate every graph by that service, without any commercial information actually 🤔
> 
> > And we will support one link target to a dynamic graph, so we don't have to update that graph every time.
> 
> This feature is still in progress :)

Yes, but you will add it into the website pipeline or accessing api7 service address every time when user accesses this team page.
Either way, you need the PMC approval(vote) to accept this.
Also, I am guessing you mean the 2nd way, then your service speed to global people matters.

> ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2106987/113494850-0e37e100-951f-11eb-876e-2abb8e020606.png)
> 
> Yes, when I try to add all projects, I find that it has too many projects 😂 Could we attach this graph for every project? (on the README file instead of website).

We removed this kind of graph including star trend from the readme. SkyWalking is focusing on GitHub for development, website for users. @Jtrust is leading all things, we have no plan to add them back.

> It's not clear for repos that don't have too many contributors when combining all of the projects.

I prefer to add this to the whole ecosystem, rather than a repo. For SkyWalking, contributions to any repo are same, and we appreciated them in same.
😂 ok, got it. But making a chart that contains multiple repos' trends is a little hard in this style. Let us reconsider.

> 😂 ok, got it. But making a chart that contains multiple repos' trends is a little hard in this style. Let us reconsider.

I just recommend to use one line in the graph. I am feeling you are thinking one line per repo

> Do you mean that application.yml cannot be modified through environment variables?

I mean the template of ElasticSearch. Removing the indices is not enough, you need to remove the template.

> ```
> webhooks:
>   http:
>     - http://127.0.0.1/notify/
>     - http://127.0.0.1/go-wechat/
>   https:
>     - key_pass: testkeypass
>       key_store_pass: testpass
>       key_store_path: "test path"
>       url: "https://ssldomain1.com/message"
>     - key_pass: testkeypass
>       key_store_pass: testpass
>       key_store_path: "test path"
>       url: "https://ssldomain1.com/message"
> ```
> 
> @wu-sheng above is proposal for same.

make sense to me.
But you should know that the alarm configuration file can't be overridden through system env, once this config in the image, it is hard to change things like this.
It is back online.

Let me make it more clear (hopefully)

We will finally have some agent images like `apache/skywalking-java-agent:<skywalking-version>-<jdk-version>`, such as `apache/skywalking-java-agent:8.5.0-jdk11`, `apache/skywalking-java-agent:8.5.0-jre8`, etc. all of which have built-in JVM options, configurations to enable the users just replace their original base image of a Java application and the SkyWalking agent is automatically installed, for example:

```dockerfile
// FROM openjdk:8 // user's original base image
FROM apache/skywalking-java-agent:8.5.0-jdk8 // only need to replace with this and the agent should be installed automatically

// Other existing stuff, including their start up command without `-javaagent` option, they don't need to be aware of this at all
```

If, however, the users want to minimize their application image, or want to do some hacking in the agent, they can do something like:


```dockerfile
FROM apache/skywalking-java-agent:8.5.0-jdk8 as agent // use our agent image as intermediate layer

// Do whatever users want, to minimize the image or anything else
```

We can also have a minimized image `apache/skywalking-java-agent:8.5.0-scratch` which only includes the agent files based on `scratch` (or `alpine`) image.

> Why do we need `apache/skywalking-java-agent:<skywalking-version>-<jdk-version>`? I mean JDK version based image?

As I said in https://github.com/apache/skywalking/pull/6686#issuecomment-813799007 , in some cases, our agent image aims to serve as the base image of users' application image, hence we need to consider the users required JDK versions, I don't mean to cover all of them, but will cover JDK 8 and JDK 11 at least

> What is the size of the current image?

~273MB, it's totally possible for the users if they want to minimize their image size

We just provide an image for convenient use of SkyWalking Java agent, there is no mandatory of any kind, not to say setting the company base image forcefully, users can choose to base their application image on our agent image, or their original base image as they want.

I'm just suggesting, if we want to provide agent image, we provide a useable one, instead of a simple wrapper of the agent jars.

I've never planned that this Docker image is designed **ONLY** for uses under Kubernetes. This is a prerequisite of my thoughts, does it work for you? If so:

here is 2 typical uses of this image:

- Traditional Docker deployment, something simply like `docker run application-based-on-this-agent`, or `docker-compose up`, under this scenario, building our agent based on `openjdk 8 / openjdk 11` is extremely helpful for users, read https://github.com/apache/skywalking/pull/6686#issuecomment-813799007 for the detailed usage.

- In Kubernetes as a sidecar, where we definitely can have an minimized image, say `apache/skywalking-java-agent:8.5.0-sidecar`, which based on `scratch / alpine`, and mounts the agent dir into the Pod where the main image resides.

All of these 2 usages can be documented in repo http://github.com/apache/skywalking-docker/ and I'll document them in https://github.com/apache/skywalking-docker/pull/17 if 👆 makes sense to you

Let's talk about this from a different perspective.
> So how SkyWalking Java Agent can do in such extreme scenarios? Because the application availability is very important, all of us won't hope the APM instrument occupies a lot of memory.

SkyWalking agent would provide a unlimited size of spans per segment, you could find the configuration in the agent, it would be 300 spans per segment mostly.

> I wonder why put the segment in the ring buffer, could we put the span? I don't familiar with the Segment design purpose.

If you don't have this concept, you can't tell the links(metrics) between entry span and exit spans, such as one day, we may need N database operations per HTTP request. Also, your codes actually cache much more data than we did for tracing the context.
**Unless, like in your case**, I would say you must put the parameter collection by yourself.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5441976/113866359-d01d1480-97df-11eb-8ec5-ee21f9955669.png)
